text.23:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that those who will attain happiness in this world and the hereafter are not only those who possess the aforementioned qualities, but also the righteous among their mothers and ancestors, as well as their closest spouses and descendants. These too will share in that happiness and prosperity, as long as they do not commit acts that cause them to lose their right to receive Allah's mercy, such as disbelief and associating partners with Allah (shirk). This verse indicates that on that Day, family relationships will be of no avail whatsoever, except for each individual's righteous deeds. Allah says:

"Then, when the Trumpet is blown, there will be no kinship among them that Day, nor will they ask of one another." (al-Muminun/23: 101)

In this regard, the Messenger of Allah (saw) once said to his daughter Fatimah az-Zahra:

"O Fatimah, daughter of Muhammad! Ask of my wealth whatever you wish, for I will not be able to help you in the least against the punishment of Allah." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abu Hurairah)

In the Quran, Allah has also affirmed the following:

"The Day when there will not benefit [anyone] wealth or children, But only one who comes to Allah with a sound heart." (asy-Syuara/26: 88-89)

Those who use their intellect as mentioned above will be placed by Allah in His Paradise. There, they will sit facing one another on beautiful couches, accompanied by those they love, namely their ancestors, family members, and children, as well as those who are worthy of entering Paradise from among the righteous, so that their hearts may be filled with joy and happiness.

That is a mercy and kindness from Allah swt to them. In addition, the angels will come to them from every direction to congratulate them on the good fortune they have obtained, which is entering Paradise. They will dwell in a home enveloped in peace, close to the prophets and messengers, and those who acknowledge the truth of Allah's religion.
text.24:
In this verse, it is mentioned that the angels come to the inhabitants of Paradise while saying greetings, "May you be safe from all undesirable and feared things, which have ruined people other than you. This fortune you obtained thanks to the patience and suffering you experienced while living life in the world."

Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari and Ibn Abi Hatim, from Umamah, narrated that the Prophet saw, during his lifetime, often came to the graves of the martyrs at the beginning of each year. There, he recited the verse. Such a thing was also done by Abu Bakr, Umar, and Usman r.a.
text.25:
There are several covenants between Allah and mankind, including the obligation for humans to acknowledge the oneness of Allah, His power and will, to believe in His prophets and the revelations He sent down, and so on. Allah SWT has provided clear evidence and arguments for all of this. However, in reality, some people have broken these covenants, in the sense that:

a. They do not pay attention to these promises, so they cannot fulfill the obligations that arise from the covenant. For example, if they truly adhered to *tauhid* (monotheism), they would certainly not worship anything other than Allah. Allah provides clear evidence of His oneness. However, they do not pay attention, so they continue to oppose the foundation of *tauhid*. They constantly embrace *shirk* (polytheism), believing in and worshiping other than Allah.

b. Initially, they paid attention to the promises they had made and the evidence that had been given. They had acknowledged and believed in its truth, but then they denied that truth and were no longer willing to practice it.

People who like to deny and violate the promises they have made are called "hypocrites" (*munafik*). In this regard, the Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

Abi Hurairah RA narrated that the Prophet SAW said, "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he always lies; when he makes a promise, he always breaks it; and when he is trusted, he betrays." (Narrated by Muslim, at-Tirmidzi, and an-Nasai)

In interpreting verse 25, Abu al-Aliyah, a *mufassir* (Quran commentator), mentioned that there are six characteristics of hypocrites that they display when they feel they have a strong position in a society, namely:

1. When they speak, they lie.

2. When they make a promise, they break it.

3. When they are given trust, they betray it.

4. They like to deny the covenant of Allah that they had previously made.

5. They like to sever the ties of kinship (*silaturrahim*) that Allah has commanded to be connected and maintained, such as relationships with His prophets who have come bringing the truth. They only believe in some of these prophets and disbelieve in others.

They also sever the ties of kinship between fellow humans, especially with the believers, but they still maintain relationships and provide assistance to the disbelievers. An example of this is that they hinder every effort that leads to the establishment of a harmonious and loving life. They do not want to see the realization of unity and solidarity among the believers, as recommended by the Prophet:

The believer to another believer is like a building, one part strengthens the other. (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, and at-Tirmidzi from Abu Musa al-Asyari)

And the words of the Prophet SAW:

The believers are like one body, if one part of it suffers, then the other parts also willingly suffer by not sleeping and feeling feverish because of it. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from an-Numan bin Basyir)

Therefore, Muslims must be careful in maintaining unity and solidarity among themselves, and not be influenced by the incitement and efforts of the hypocrites to divide that unity.

c. They like to commit corruption on earth, whether in the form of injustice they commit against themselves or injustice they commit against the property of others in an unlawful way, or by creating slander and disasters in Muslim society, and inciting hostility and war against them.

At the end of this verse, Allah establishes a fitting punishment to be inflicted on the hypocrites, considering the evil of their behavior and actions. The punishment is the curse of Allah, which is to distance them from His mercy, so that they are excluded from the goodness of this world and the hereafter. They will meet a very bad end, namely the torment of Hell, as a reward for the evil and sins they have committed.
text.26:
Allah expands and facilitates sustenance for some of His servants as He wills, so they obtain more sustenance than their daily needs. They are those who are diligent and skilled in seeking wealth, and engage in various endeavors. In addition, they are thrifty and prudent, and wise in managing and utilizing their wealth.

Conversely, Allah also restricts sustenance for some of His servants, so that the sustenance they obtain is no more than what is needed for daily life. They are usually lazy and unskilled in seeking wealth, or not wise in managing and utilizing that wealth.

Allah expands and restricts the sustenance of His servants based on His wisdom and knowledge of each servant. These two things are not related to the level of faith and disbelief of His servants. Therefore, there are times when Allah bestows abundant sustenance upon His disbelieving servants. Conversely, sometimes Allah restricts sustenance for believers to increase the reward they will receive in the Hereafter. So wealth and poverty are two things that can happen to believers and disbelievers alike, the righteous and the wicked.

This verse further narrates that the polytheists of Mecca, who like to break Allah's promises, are very happy with the abundance of material possessions they have, and the abundant worldly life, and they think that these material possessions are the greatest blessing and fortune.

Therefore, at the end of this verse, Allah points out their error, and affirms that the pleasures of worldly life are only small pleasures, short in duration, and easily and quickly lost, compared to the pleasures in the Hereafter which are of great value and everlasting. Thus, it is not appropriate for them to be proud of the worldly pleasures they feel.

In this regard, a narration conveyed by Imam at-Tirmidhi from Ibn Mas'ud mentions the following:

The Messenger of Allah once slept on a mat, then he woke up from his sleep, and the marks of the mat were visible on his side. Then we said, "O Messenger of Allah, if only we could get you a bed!" The Messenger of Allah said, "What is the meaning of this world to me? I live in this world only like a rider who takes shelter for a moment under a tree, then he leaves again and leaves the tree." (Riwayat at-Tirmidzi dari Ibnu Masud)
text.27:
After explaining that the polytheists are captivated by the mirage of worldly life and delighted with small pleasures, Allah mentions the consequences arising from their erroneous attitudes and views by proposing to the Prophet Muhammad that a verse be revealed to him from God that would prove his prophethood and apostleship. Among them were Abu Sufyan bin Harb (before converting to Islam), Abdullah bin Abi Umayyah, and his companions. They once said, "Why are not signs sent down to Muhammad as were sent down to the prophets and messengers of old, such as the sky falling in pieces upon them, turning Mount Safa into gold, or moving the mountains from around the city of Mecca, so that the vacant places could be turned into gardens?" Their other sayings are mentioned in the Qur'an, including the one found in the following verse:

"Bring us a sign just as the messengers of old were sent with." (al-Anbiya/21: 5)

With such statements, it is as if all the clear signs and proofs given to the Prophet Muhammad, such as the Qur'an and others, are not clear proofs of his apostleship capable of encouraging them to obey and believe in Allah, or as a truth that cannot be doubted.

Furthermore, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to explain to those polytheists that the sending down of those signs does not play a role in making someone guided or misguided. Everything is in the power of Allah alone. Only Allah swt is able to mislead whom He wills, and guide those who like to repent to the path that pleases Him.

Even though the Prophet Muhammad has miracles that prove his apostleship, it will not be beneficial in making someone believe. What a person must do to believe is to be humble, obedient, and ask Allah swt for guidance, in order to obtain good fortune in this world and the hereafter, and avoid the deception and temptation of Satan.

For those who believe, the Qur'an is a miracle that proves the apostleship of the Prophet Muhammad, so no other proofs are needed. Conversely, the polytheists are immersed in error and denial, so any evidence or miracles shown by the Messenger of Allah will not make them believers.
text.28: In this verse, Allah explains those who receive His guidance, namely those who believe and whose hearts find peace in the remembrance of Allah. By remembering Allah, the heart becomes tranquil and the soul becomes calm, without feeling anxious, afraid, or worried. They do good deeds, and feel happy with the virtues they perform.
text.29: This verse explains that those who believe and do righteous deeds will certainly obtain happiness and a good place of return with Allah on the Last Day.
text.30:
This verse explains that Allah has sent Prophet Muhammad to a people who had never received the arrival of a messenger of Allah. Although there had been other peoples before who had been visited by His messengers, they still denied the existence of the Most Merciful God.

Allah SWT explains that the duty of Prophet Muhammad is to recite to his people the Al-Quran that has been revealed to him. Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad SAW to say to his people that Allah is the Lord of the universe, there is no God but Allah, and only to Him does he trust and repent. Therefore, his people should believe in Him.

Prophet Muhammad was also commanded to convey to his people that he trusts and repents to Allah SWT, even though he is a prophet and messenger of Allah who never committed sin. If a messenger still does so, what more those who are sinners, of course they are more worthy to trust and repent to Allah from all the sins they have committed.
text.31:
In this verse, Allah explains the greatness of the Quran as a miracle of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). However, before that, this verse explains that even if there were a reading or Holy Book that could cause mountains to move, the earth to be split apart, or the dead to come back to life and speak, there would still be people who would not believe.

The meaning of the above statement is that Allah had given miracles to Prophet Musa, such as Mount Tur being able to move, and a rock being able to gush forth springs after being struck with his staff. Allah SWT also gave miracles to Prophet Isa, so that he could bring the dead back to life. To Prophet Muhammad, Allah gave the greatest miracle, which is the Quran, a miracle that is eternal and can still be seen today. The Quran contains evidence that shows the greatness of Allah's power and the beauty of His creation. In addition, the Quran brings wisdom, laws, and regulations that humans need to regulate life in various fields, be it economic, political, social, and so on, which guarantees a happy life in this world and the hereafter if they are willing to understand and practice it. Thus, they will emerge as the best nation and people on this earth.

According to ath-Thabrani from Ibn Abbas, a group of polytheists of Mecca, including Abu Jahal and Abdullah bin Abi Umayyah, held a meeting behind the Kaaba, and sent someone to call the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). He then came to their place, and Abdullah bin Abi Umayyah said to him that they would be willing to become his followers if he could prove the miraculous nature of the Quran to move the mountains around Mecca, so that the place would become spacious and could be used as agricultural land. If the Messenger of Allah could do this, then they would believe that he was truly a prophet and messenger. They also asked the Messenger of Allah to be able to control the wind and make it a vehicle for going back and forth from Mecca to the land of Syria. According to them, this would prove that Muhammad was truly a prophet and messenger of Allah like Prophet Sulaiman who was able to use the wind as a vehicle. In addition, they also asked Muhammad (peace be upon him) to revive their ancestors who had long died, such as Qushai bin Kilab or anyone they wanted among their dead ancestors. They would ask the person who was revived whether the da'wah conveyed by Muhammad (peace be upon him) was true or not. According to them, this was to prove that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was truly a prophet and messenger of Allah as was Prophet Isa (peace be upon him) who with his miracle could bring the dead back to life.

Allah SWT then revealed the verse above to affirm that if Allah granted what they asked for as part of the miraculous nature of the Quran, it would certainly happen, because everything is under His power. However, if this were actually granted, they still would not believe in Allah, Prophet Muhammad, and the Quran which is his miracle.

Prophet Muhammad very much wanted them to believe, but they still did not believe, and even made various requests. Therefore, in this verse, Allah SWT gives comfort to him by affirming that he and the believers must truly understand that if Allah wanted all people to believe, Allah would surely give guidance to them all. In addition, the believers must also believe that the disbelievers will always be afflicted with disasters and the wrath of Allah because of their disbelief and evil deeds. The disaster could happen near their place of residence, so that finally what Allah promised would come, namely their own destruction.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that Allah's promise to help the Muslims and destroy the disbelievers will surely happen, because Allah will not break His promise.
text.32: This verse contains comfort for the Messenger of Allah and the Muslim community, so that they are not discouraged by the attitudes and denial of the disbelievers and polytheists of Mecca. Here, Allah SWT explains that it was not only the Prophet Muhammad who was mocked by the disbelieving and polytheistic people; the messengers whom Allah had sent to them before also experienced the same situation. However, Allah gave them a respite and postponed the coming of torment and disaster to those disbelievers. In the end, Allah will surely destroy them with a terrible torment.
text.33:
In this verse, Allah swt rebukes the ignorance of the disbelievers and polytheists who worship other than Allah, namely objects they consider to be their gods, which cannot provide benefit or harm, do not know what humans do, and cannot supervise or give rewards or punishments to humans based on their deeds and actions. Allah says, "Is Allah, who oversees their actions, the same as what they deify, which does not have such qualities?"

Because the polytheists associate partners with Allah swt, Allah commands His Messenger to say to them, "Name the attributes possessed by what you consider to be rivals or partners of Allah!" They all completely lack the attributes of perfection that Allah swt possesses. Therefore, it is not fitting for them to be His partners.

Their words and demands to the Prophet Muhammad, as mentioned above, also give the impression that they assume Allah does not know what is happening on earth. Therefore, in this verse, Allah swt questions them, are they uttering those words with the intention of informing Allah swt about events happening on earth that they assume Allah does not know? Whereas Allah knows everything that happens in this universe.

Because those polytheists associate others with Allah, in this verse, Allah swt commands the Prophet Muhammad to ask them, are they mentioning Allah's "partners" merely as outward expressions, and do they not have any true reality at all? If that is the case, then their words are nonsense that have no true reality at all. Whereas Allah has no partners at all. He is the Most High and Most Perfect.

At the end of this verse, Allah swt reveals the secret of the misguidance of the disbelievers and polytheists, which is that they have been captivated by various temptations of Satan, who portrays to them that the deception they commit is a good and praiseworthy deed. Because they have followed the seduction of Satan, they have been prevented and diverted from the path of Allah. Whoever has deviated from the path of Allah, then there is no one who can guide those people because they have followed the will of Satan.
text.34: This verse explains how unfortunate the fate of those who are astray is, and how great the loss they suffer, namely: the misery of life in this world, while in the Hereafter they will be punished even more severely. They will not find a protector from the punishment of Allah.
text.35:
One of the habits of the Al-Quran is that after mentioning matters pertaining to hell, it is usually followed by mentioning matters pertaining to paradise, which is full of pleasures that will be obtained by those who believe, are pious, and do good deeds.

In this verse, the paradise that Allah has promised to the pious is likened to a beautiful and fertile garden because it is traversed by rivers. Its trees are depicted as bearing fruit incessantly and providing shade to those who take shelter beneath them. That paradise is the final and eternal abode for the pious.

Conversely, hell is a dwelling place full of misery for the disbelievers.

By depicting the comparison between these two places, humans who live in this world are invited to choose the path to paradise through faith, good deeds, and piety, or the path to hell through disbelief, polytheism, and evil deeds.
text.36:
This verse explains the attitude of the People of the Book (Jews and Christians) towards the Quran after they embraced Islam, such as Abdullah bin Salam from among the Jews. They were very happy with the revelation of the Quran and accepted all its teachings and laws. However, besides them, there was also a group of Jews and Christians who denied parts of the Quran, especially regarding the teaching of the oneness of Allah swt.

Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to convey to this group the steadfastness of his faith in Allah swt, by saying, "Indeed, I am only commanded to worship Allah alone, and I will not associate anything with Him. I call people to believe only in Him, and I am certain that only to Him will I return."

This statement of the Messenger firmly rejects the belief of shirk, which is associating something with Allah as practiced by the polytheists. This belief is in stark contrast to the Quran's teaching about the absolute oneness of Allah, which is the core of the Islamic religion.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah explains several main characteristics of the Quran that was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw, namely that the Quran contains correct regulations that must be obeyed by humans to achieve happiness and good fortune in this world and the hereafter. In addition, the Quran was revealed in Arabic, a language that possesses several advantages not found in other languages.

Among the advantages of the Arabic language is that it is a language that had already developed long before the arrival of Islam, making its vocabulary very rich. Arabic also has rules of word formation (morphology) that allow it to easily accommodate new concepts for the formation of new words. Thus, the ability of the Arabic language to express the concepts of revelation can be understood. Because the Quran is in Arabic, the Quran has preserved the Arabic language so that it is not lost like Syriac, Coptic, and so on.

Because the Quran was revealed in Arabic and is a miracle of the Prophet Muhammad as a holy book, translations of the Quran into foreign languages are not considered holy books. As is known, among the honors possessed by the Quran is that reading it is considered an act of worship, and it may not be touched except by those who are pure, namely those who are not in a state of major or minor ritual impurity.

Many verses mention the characteristics of the Quran, including the word of Allah swt:

"(Falsehood cannot approach it from before it or from behind it; [it is] a revelation from a [Lord who is] Wise and Praiseworthy." (Fushshilat/41: 42)

Furthermore, Allah swt warns the Prophet Muhammad saw and Muslims in general, not to follow the desires and wishes of those who deny the Quran, either in part or in its entirety, because Allah swt has given them true knowledge, namely the Al-Quran al-Karim. If the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims are tempted and follow the wishes of those who deny the Quran, then Allah's punishment will surely befall them, and no one can be a protector against the punishment of Allah swt, the Almighty.
text.38:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that He sent messengers before Prophet Muhammad SAW, and they had wives and offspring.

This shows that family life and having offspring are natural and a *sunnatullah* (divine law/practice) for His creatures living on this earth. This *sunnatullah* also applies to His prophets and messengers. Family life should not be considered an obstacle in the struggle, whether for personal, community, or national progress. In fact, marriage according to Islamic teachings, besides aiming to continue offspring, also functions to provide peace, tranquility, and stability in life. Marriage also strengthens *silaturrahim* (kinship ties) between the families involved and can be a means of Islamic *dakwah* (propagation), as was done by the Prophet Muhammad SAW.

Because family life is natural and a *sunnatullah*, humans should not oppose it. Therefore, it is wrong if there are religious leaders who have the assumption that they must avoid family life, so as not to interfere with practicing religion. The attitude of celibacy or *tabattul* is something that is not known in Islam, and is even strongly opposed. Marriage and children are blessings and mercy from Allah to His servants. Therefore, marriage and family need to be maintained and preserved as well as possible.

In one narration, it is mentioned that the Jews criticized Prophet Muhammad SAW because he had several wives. They said that if Muhammad was truly a prophet and messenger, he would devote himself to his prophetic duties and would not care about women. They also asked for various proofs of his prophethood, besides the Al-Quran which was his miracle. Allah SWT has refuted them by affirming that Prophet Muhammad was not the first messenger of Allah, but before that Allah SWT had sent several messengers and all of them were ordinary humans who needed to eat, drink, have families and offspring, and do the things that other people did, walk in the market, and so on. In this case, Allah SWT commanded Prophet Muhammad SAW to affirm:

"Say, "I am only a man like you, to whom has been revealed that your god is but one God." (al-Kahf/18: 110)

Then, in this verse, the naturalness and permissibility of the messengers living in families and having offspring is emphasized. Allah affirms that He bestowed upon them wives and offspring.

In a *hadith* narrated by Imam al-Bukhari and Imam Muslim from Anas bin Malik, it is mentioned that Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

"As for me, I fast and break my fast, I pray at night, and I sleep, I also eat meat and marry women; so whoever does not like my *sunnah* (way of life) is not one of my *ummah* (community)." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

As for the verses or proofs of prophethood and messengership that the disbelievers demanded from Prophet Muhammad SAW, it is answered repeatedly in the Al-Quran that the matter is the sole authority of Allah. The messengers only show their miracles with Allah's permission.

The greatest miracle of Prophet Muhammad SAW is the Al-Quran, which brings teachings, laws, and regulations that play a role in guiding humans to happiness in this world and the hereafter. The Al-Quran is always preserved in its purity and no creature can match it, both in terms of its content and its linguistic wording.

Verses or proofs and miracles do not appear just like that, but must be in accordance with Allah's wisdom and in harmony with the times. Each period has its own characteristics that Allah has determined. Every event that occurs in this universe follows His provisions or *taqdir* (destiny), both regarding the time, place, manner, and causes of its occurrence. Miracles will not appear before the time that Allah has determined. A person's death, sustenance, and events experienced in this world and the hereafter occur according to Allah's provisions. Humans cannot ask for their death to come sooner or later than what Allah has determined in His *taqdir*.
text.39:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains one aspect of His power, which is to erase or establish whatever He wills, whether concerning His laws (Sharia) or the fate of mankind.

Signs of Allah's erasure and establishment are the existence of day and night that come in succession, the existence of darkness and light, life and death, strength and weakness, health and sickness, happiness and misery, wealth and poverty, and so on.

At the end of this verse, Allah SWT explains that with Him, or in the Lauh Mahfudh, is the Ummul Kitab (Mother of the Book). All events and occurrences that happen in this universe are written in the Lauh Mahfudh, which will not undergo any changes or replacements whatsoever.

Based on this understanding, this verse is also a refutation of the demands of the disbelievers and polytheists who asked the Prophet Muhammad SAW to bring verses or proofs of his prophethood and apostleship, other than the Al-Quran. This will never happen, unless it is included in the provisions established by Allah or already exists in the Lauh Mahfudh.
text.40: In this verse, it is explained that there is a possibility that Allah will grant the Messenger a long life, so that he has the opportunity to witness the arrival of the punishment that has been promised to the disbelievers. It is also possible that Allah will grant the Messenger a short life so that he does not have the opportunity to witness the punishment that He sends down. The duty of His Messenger is only to preach the religion of Islam to mankind. As for the matter of whether they want to accept or reject it, that is Allah's affair. For those who reject, Allah's punishment will surely come, whether it is hastened or delayed, is Allah's prerogative.
text.41:
In this verse, Allah SWT also demonstrates another aspect of His power in inflicting punishment upon the disbelievers, namely by gradually reducing the extent of their land. This reduction in their territory may be due to natural disasters that Allah sends upon them, causing some of their land to be damaged and uninhabitable; or it may be due to war, so that their territory is conquered by other nations and they are pushed back or expelled from their land.

Furthermore, this verse explains Allah's power in establishing laws according to His wisdom and will, and the laws that He has established cannot be rejected or refuted by anyone.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is swift in reckoning the deeds of His servants, so that those who believe and do good deeds will receive a reward of goodness, while those who deny Him and commit injustice will surely receive His punishment and wrath. All the deeds of His servants will not escape Allah's reckoning.
text.42:
Allah further explains another aspect of His power, namely in confronting the deception perpetrated by the disbelievers of Mecca against the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims. Allah explains that the disbelievers before the time of the Messenger of Allah also engaged in deception against His messengers. But all their deception was under the power of Allah, so it would not destroy the religion and His messengers. Allah always knows in advance everything that is done by every creature of His.

From this, it can be understood that if the deception of the disbelievers against the previous messengers of Allah was under the power of Allah, then surely the deception of the disbelievers of Mecca against the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims is also under the power of Allah. Thus, this deception will not succeed in destroying the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims, and will not be able to prevent the spread of Islam.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the disbelievers will surely know in the future that those who are entitled to obtain the final and eternal abode full of pleasure are only those who believe and do righteous deeds.
text.43:
This verse illustrates the dialogue between the disbelievers of Mecca and the Messenger of Allah, in which they denied his prophethood by saying, "You are not a messenger." To confront their denial, Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to answer them by saying, "Sufficient is Allah as a witness in the dispute that occurs between us regarding my prophethood. Those who have knowledge of the Scripture from among you who have embraced Islam can be witnesses to the truth of my prophethood."

In accordance with Allah's affirmation in the previous verse that the primary duty of Prophet Muhammad is to convey the religion of Islam to mankind, he need not be anxious in the face of the disbelieving attitude of those disbelievers, because it is Allah who raised and sent him as a messenger.

The scholars of the People of the Book chose to embrace Islam because they already knew that in the Gospel and the Torah, which Allah revealed to Prophet Isa and Prophet Musa, there was clear information about the coming of the last prophet and messenger, namely Muhammad, peace be upon him. Therefore, they did not deny his prophethood at all.
